questionContent.body: The minimum number of attributes required to uniquely identify a tuple is

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Candidate key is the minimal superkey unique and smallest in size.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is not a constraint in the relational model

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Transition constraints are from temporal DBs not in basic relational model.

questionContent.body: In a relation, no attribute should have multiple values. This is ensured by

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: 1NF requires all attributes to be atomic.

questionContent.body: Which relational algebra operator is used to rename fields

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Rename (?) assigns new names to relations or attributes.

questionContent.body: In the ER model, aggregation is used when

questionOptions.body: We need to represent an attribute of a relationship
We want to merge two entities

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Aggregation treats a relationship set as an entity for higher-level relations.

questionContent.body: In the relational model, which of the following is a property of candidate keys

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Candidate keys uniquely identify each tuple and are minimal (no subset is a key)

questionContent.body: What is the minimum number of tables needed to convert a ternary relationship into relational schema

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: One for each participating entity (3) and one for the ternary relationship = 4 total, but 3 relations at minimum assuming one combined.

questionContent.body: Which of the following does not affect normalization

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Entity identifiers are part of the conceptual model, not relational normalization.

questionContent.body: A relation has no NULL values and each attribute is atomic. The relation is in

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: 1NF requires atomicity of attribute values, but not necessarily elimination of NULLs.

questionContent.body: A derived attribute in an ER diagram is represented by

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Derived attributes are represented using dashed ovals (e.g., Age derived from DOB).

questionContent.body: If two attributes A and B form a composite key, then both A and B are

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Attributes that are part of any candidate key are called prime attributes.

questionContent.body: Which of the following operations is not part of relational algebra

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Group By is part of SQL, not basic relational algebra.

questionContent.body: In ER diagrams, a diamond shape represents

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Rectangles for entities, ovals for attributes, diamonds for relationships.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is used to uniquely identify a weak entity

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Weak entities are identified using a foreign key from a strong entity and their partial key.

questionContent.body: If a relation R satisfies 1NF, 2NF, and 3NF but not BCNF, then

questionOptions.body: It has a non-prime attribute functionally determining a key
Every determinant is a candidate key

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Violation of BCNF happens when a non-candidate key determines part of the primary key.

questionContent.body: Which of the following best describes a foreign key

questionOptions.body: An attribute that uniquely identifies a tuple
A primary key in the same table
An attribute in one table referring to a primary key in another table
A key used only for sorting

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Foreign keys enforce referential integrity between tables.

questionContent.body: Generalization in ER modeling is

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Generalization groups multiple entities into a higher-level one.

questionContent.body: Which of the following statements is false about a candidate key

questionOptions.body: It can be a composite key
There can be multiple candidate keys

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Candidate keys cannot contain NULLs because they must uniquely identify tuples.

questionContent.body: Mapping a many-to-many relationship in ER model requires

questionOptions.body: A new relation with foreign keys from both entities
Creating a composite key from one entity

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Many-to-many relationships are resolved using a new table with foreign keys from both entities.

questionContent.body: Which of these is not a feature of the relational model

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Attribute names define order, but logically attributes are considered unordered.

questionContent.body: A relation is in 1NF if

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: 1NF ensures that all attribute values are indivisible.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is true about weak entities

questionOptions.body: They have their own primary key
They depend on a strong entity for identification
They do not participate in relationships

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Weak entities rely on foreign key from a related strong entity and a partial key.

questionContent.body: If a relation R has 5 attributes and 2000 tuples, what is the degree and cardinality of R

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Degree = columns, Cardinality = number of rows.

questionContent.body: Which one of the following is not a valid relationship type in an ER model

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: One-to-Self is not a formal term. Recursive relationships are allowed but not named like this.

questionContent.body: A relation schema has 2 candidate keys: {A, B} and {C, D}. Which of these is not allowed

questionOptions.body: A and C as foreign keys
Both {A, B} and {C, D} as primary keys
Choosing {A, B} as primary and {C, D} as alternate
Choosing a subset of {A, B} as primary key

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A candidate key is minimal; its subset cannot be a key.

questionContent.body: Which of the following cannot be a primary key

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Primary keys should remain stable and unchanged.

questionContent.body: The cardinality ratio in an ER model tells us

questionOptions.body: Number of entity instances that can be associated

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Cardinality defines the number of entities that participate in a relationship.

questionContent.body: Which of the following attributes can be part of a composite key

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Composite keys are made up of simple attributes only.

questionContent.body: The disjoint rule in generalization specifies that

questionOptions.body: An entity can belong to multiple subclasses
An entity can belong to exactly one subclass

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Disjoint rule = entity belongs to only one of the subclasses.

questionContent.body: If a relation is in 2NF and no transitive dependency exists, it is in

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: This is the condition for a relation to qualify as 3NF.

questionContent.body: Which normal form ensures no transitive dependency exists in a relation

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: 3NF removes transitive dependencies while preserving dependency preservation.

questionContent.body: The cross product of two relations R with m tuples and S with n tuples will have

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Cartesian product returns every combination of tuples from both relations.

questionContent.body: In an ER diagram, attributes that can take more than one value for an entity are

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Example: A person may have multiple phone numbers.

questionContent.body: In a relational schema, if A ? B and B ? C, then A ? C is an example of

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Transitivity in functional dependencies implies indirect determination.

questionContent.body: Which one of the following operations is not a basic operation of relational algebra

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Violation of BCNF happens when a non-candidate key determines part of the primary key.

questionContent.body: Which of the following best defines the concept of referential integrity

questionOptions.body: No two rows have the same primary key
Foreign key values must match primary key values in another table or be null

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Referential integrity ensures valid links between tables.

questionContent.body: The minimum number of tables required to represent an ER model with ternary relationship is

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: One relation for each entity (3), and one for the ternary relationship (1) ? 3+1 = 4. But ternary implies at least 3 relations (entity + combined relation).

questionContent.body: A multivalued dependency exists when

questionOptions.body: One attribute determines many others independently
One attribute determines a unique value

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A ? B means for a single A, there can be multiple independent B values.

questionContent.body: In an ER model, total participation is represented by

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A double line connects the entity to the relationship to indicate total participation.

questionContent.body: A composite attribute in ER model is

questionOptions.body: An attribute with a multivalued dependency
An attribute consisting of multiple sub-parts
An attribute repeated over multiple entities

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Example: Name ? {FirstName, LastName}

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a valid foreign key constraint action

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: ON UPDATE CASCADE is used to automatically update foreign key values.

questionContent.body: Which of the following cannot be a candidate key

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Candidate keys must be minimal; redundant keys are not allowed.

questionContent.body: The key difference between a primary key and a unique key is

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Unique key allows one null value, while primary key doesn't allow any.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a valid mapping for a ternary relationship

questionOptions.body: Merge it into one of the entities
Create a new relation with all entity keys

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Ternary relationships are mapped as a separate relation containing all participating primary keys.

questionContent.body: The degree of a relation refers to

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Degree = number of columns (attributes) in a relation.

questionContent.body: Which is not a property of a relation in the relational model

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A relation cannot have duplicate tuples; each one is unique.

questionContent.body: Derived attributes in an ER model are represented by

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Derived attributes (like age from DOB) are shown using dashed ovals.

questionContent.body: What is a superkey in a relational schema

questionOptions.body: A set of attributes that uniquely identifies a tuple
A composite key with only prime attributes

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Any set of attributes that uniquely identifies rows is a superkey.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a many-to-many relationship example

questionOptions.body: Customer ï¿½ Owns ï¿½ Account (in a bank)

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A student can enroll in many courses, and a course can have many students.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is true about foreign keys

questionOptions.body: Must match a candidate key in another table

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Foreign keys can consist of multiple columns referencing a composite primary key.

questionContent.body: The ER model is useful for

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The ER model is a high-level conceptual design tool.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is not a valid relational algebra operator

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Rename is part of extended relational algebra, not basic core.

questionContent.body: The participation of an entity set in a relationship set is said to be total if

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Total participation = every entity of the set must be involved in the relationship.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a valid candidate key

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A candidate key is a minimal set of attributes that can uniquely identify a tuple.

questionContent.body: What does a diamond symbol represent in an ER diagram

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Relationships are denoted by diamond shapes in ER diagrams.

questionContent.body: A relation is in 1NF if

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Each row in a relation is called a tuple.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is true about a weak entity

questionOptions.body: It always has a primary key
It depends on a strong entity

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: 1NF requires attributes to hold atomic (indivisible) values.

questionContent.body: In an ER diagram, a double rectangle represents

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A weak entity relies on a strong one for identification.
